questions.text: A 10-year-old girl is brought to the physician by her mother because of a 10-day history of a pruritic rash. The mother reports that she initially noticed a single round lesion on the child's upper abdomen that gradually increased in size; smaller lesions have since spread over her trunk, neck, and both arms. The child also had a fever, sore throat, and malaise a week before the onset of the rash. The child and her family recently went for a picnic in the woods around their house, but the mother does not recall seeing any ticks on the child. She has no significant past medical history and does not take any medications. She has not received any childhood vaccines because her parents believe that the risks of side effects are worse than the conditions. Her temperature is 36.8 °C (98.4 °F), pulse is 86/min, and blood pressure is 90/60 mm Hg. Physical examination shows the findings in the photograph. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Tinea corporis manifests with pruritic, round, erythematous plaques with scaling, central clearing, and raised borders, similar to what is seen in this patient. However, tinea corporis usually develops slowly and is not preceded by prodromal symptoms. Additionally, the rash does not start with a single, larger lesion followed by a secondary eruption of smaller, similar lesions.
Image Description:

Left outer thigh of a male patient with a erythematous, marginated lesion that has a map-like appearance and central pallor without scaling. The patient has tinea corporis caused by dermatophytes, which is usually associated with severe pruritus.

B) INCORRECT:

In the early localized stage, Lyme disease often manifests with a single erythematous lesion with central clearing (erythema migrans) that can be followed by a secondary stage where multiple lesions develop. In addition, patients with Lyme disease often have flu-like symptoms in the early stages of the disease. Unlike in this 10-year-old girl, however, lesions of erythema migrans are neither scaly nor pruritic and, instead, have a typical bull's-eye appearance. Finally, in Lyme disease, the secondary eruption develops weeks after the primary lesion, whereas this patient's secondary eruption developed a few days after the initial one.
Image Description:

A circular erythematous rash with a central clearing (“bulls-eye” rash) is visible on the upper back.

Erythema migrans is typically seen in the early localized stage of Lyme disease.

C) INCORRECT:

Pityriasis versicolor manifests with scaly macules that are typically found on the chest and the trunk and can be accompanied by pruritus. However, this condition is also characterized by round, sharply demarcated macules that can be hyperpigmented or hypopigmented. Also, patients with pityriasis versicolor do not usually present with prodromal symptoms and the rash does not start with a single, larger lesion followed by a secondary eruption of smaller, similar lesions.
Image Description:

Numerous hypopigmented, well-demarcated macules are visible on the patient's back. The lesions show fine scaling and coalesce in some regions.

This is the typical appearance of pityriasis versicolor.

D) CORRECT:

Pityriasis rosea is a self-limited condition that most commonly affects children > 10 years of age and young adults. Although the exact etiology is unknown, pityriasis rosea is thought to be triggered by a viral infection. Some patients experience a prodromal phase with flu-like symptoms 1–2 weeks prior to rash onset, as seen here. The initial eruption typically appears as a single ovoid macule that is 1–5 cm in diameter, also known as a herald patch. This plaque is usually salmon-colored, slightly raised, and surrounded by a scaly, white collarette. The secondary eruption develops about 2–21 days later and is characterized by bilateral diffuse, oval-shaped papules and plaques that are smaller than the herald patch. Patients can also experience pruritus, for which topical emollients and/ or oral antihistamines may be prescribed. The rash typically resolves spontaneously in 6–12 weeks.
Image Description:

Initial eruption (herald patch) and secondary eruption on the trunk

The herald patch (black arrow) is ovoid with a raised dark border and central clearing. The secondary eruption consists of scattered papules and plaques on an erythematous base.

E) INCORRECT:

Nummular eczema manifests with large, coin-shaped, well-demarcated erythematous plaques that are pruritic and scaly. However, nummular eczema primarily affects the extremities and the lesions are usually confined to a smaller area. Also, patients with this condition do not present with prodromal symptoms and the rash does not begin with a single, larger lesion followed by a secondary eruption of smaller, similar lesions.
Image Description:

Several red-brown, round, crusted, and slightly scaly plaques can be seen on the back of the hands, fingers, and lower arm.

F) INCORRECT:

Measles most commonly affects young children and manifests with a prodromal stage followed by an erythematous maculopapular rash, similar to what is seen here. Furthermore, this patient has not received any childhood vaccinations, which puts her at increased risk of developing measles. In the prodromal stage, however, patients with measles usually present with coryza, cough, and conjunctivitis. Measles manifests with a rash that originates behind the ears before spreading to the trunk and the extremities instead of a single, larger lesion followed by a secondary eruption with smaller, similar lesions. Finally, the rash is typically accompanied by fever and lymphadenopathy, neither of which is seen here.
Image Description:

Photograph of a toddler

There is a generalized erythematous maculopapular exanthem. Some confluence is visible (e.g., on the upper thighs).

G) INCORRECT:

Guttate psoriasis most commonly occurs after streptococcal infections, which can manifest with fever, sore throat, and pharyngeal inflammation. Although guttate psoriasis also originates from the trunk and manifests with numerous, erythematous, scaly lesions, the papules are typically droplet-shaped and smaller than the lesions seen in this patient. Additionally, the rash does not start with a single, larger lesion followed by a secondary eruption of smaller, similar lesions.
Image Description:

Multiple small scaly erythematous lesions are visible.

This appearance is typical of guttate psoriasis and is most often precipitated by group A streptococcal infection.
questions.hint: The lesions associated with this condition are oriented along cleavage (Langers) lines, which align on the back like the branches of a Christmas tree, resulting in a characteristic Christmas tree pattern.

questions.text:
A 45-year-old man reports a 3-week history of a rash that began several weeks after a flulike illness. The eruption started with the development of a large, scaly, pink plaque on his flank (figure 1) followed a few days later by multiple other similar lesions (figure 2). The eruption has not responded to topical antifungal or glucocorticoid ointments.
Physical examination reveals scaly, ovoid pink papules and plaques aligned in a “Christmas-tree” pattern along skin tension lines on the patient’s back and flanks. There is involvement of the abdomen, proximal extremities, and palms. No lymphadenopathy is noted, and his oropharynx is clear. A recent HIV test was negative.
Which one of the following tests is most appropriate for this patient?

choices.text: Bacterial swab culture of the pharynx
Human herpesvirus-8 staining of skin biopsy

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

A beta-lactam antibiotic-related morbilliform eruption typically occurs with mononucleosis infection. It can affect the palms and soles, often with pharyngitis and lymphadenopathy, but not in a Christmas-tree distribution. In addition, the eruption depicted here is papulosquamous, not morbilliform.

B) CORRECT:

Pityriasis rosea is a common, self-limited skin eruption affecting mostly adolescents and young adults. The cause of pityriasis rosea is not known. Flulike symptoms may occur. Classically, a single pink, scaly plaque develops, followed by an eruption of smaller ovoid, scaly pink papules on the torso and proximal extremities. On the back, ovoid lesions tend to align along skin tension lines. This Christmas-tree pattern is suggestive of pityriasis rosea but is not specific. In patients who have pityriasis rosea with atypical features (older age and/or palmoplantar involvement), obtaining a treponemal antibody test is recommended to rule out secondary syphilis since the rash of pityriasis rosea can look very similar to that associated with syphilis.

Key learning point: A sexually transmitted infection that can clinically mimic pityriasis rosea is secondary syphilis.

C) INCORRECT:

Guttate psoriasis — which is often associated with streptococcal infection — occurs predominantly in children, is characterized by smaller lesions with a thicker scale, and lacks a Christmas-tree distribution.

D) INCORRECT:

Kaposi sarcoma is associated with human herpesvirus 8 and is characterized by reddish-purple patches, plaques, or nodules, sometimes in a Christmas-tree distribution.

E) INCORRECT:

A fungal infection does not occur in a Christmas-tree distribution, nor is it associated with pityriasis rosea.

questions.text: You are seeing a 10-year-old girl who is brought to your clinic by her mother because of a 10-day history of a pruritic rash. Her mother reports that the rash began as a single round lesion on the upper abdomen that gradually increased in size, followed by the appearance of smaller lesions over the trunk, neck, and both arms. The child had fever, sore throat, and malaise one week before the rash started. She has no significant past medical history and takes no medications. Her temperature is 36.8°C. On physical examination, the findings are shown in the photograph. Which one of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Guttate psoriasis most commonly occurs after streptococcal infections, which can manifest with fever, sore throat, and pharyngeal inflammation. Although guttate psoriasis also originates from the trunk and manifests with numerous, erythematous, scaly lesions, the papules are typically droplet-shaped and smaller than the lesions seen in this patient. Additionally, the rash does not start with a single, larger lesion followed by a secondary eruption of smaller, similar lesions.

B) INCORRECT:

Nummular eczema manifests with large, coin-shaped, well-demarcated erythematous plaques that are pruritic and scaly. However, nummular eczema primarily affects the extremities and the lesions are usually confined to a smaller area. Also, patients with this condition do not present with prodromal symptoms and the rash does not begin with a single, larger lesion followed by a secondary eruption of smaller, similar lesions.

C) INCORRECT:

Tinea corporis manifests with pruritic, round, erythematous plaques with scaling, central clearing, and raised borders, similar to what is seen in this patient. However, tinea corporis usually develops slowly and is not preceded by prodromal symptoms. Additionally, the rash does not start with a single, larger lesion followed by a secondary eruption of smaller, similar lesions.

D) INCORRECT:

Pityriasis versicolor manifests with scaly macules that are typically found on the chest and the trunk and can be accompanied by pruritus. However, this condition is also characterized by round, sharply demarcated macules that can be hyperpigmented or hypopigmented. Also, patients with pityriasis versicolor do not usually present with prodromal symptoms and the rash does not start with a single, larger lesion followed by a secondary eruption of smaller, similar lesions.

E) CORRECT:

Pityriasis rosea is a self-limited condition that most commonly affects children > 10 years of age and young adults. Although the exact etiology is unknown, pityriasis rosea is thought to be triggered by a viral infection. Some patients experience a prodromal phase with flu-like symptoms 1–2 weeks prior to rash onset, as seen here. The initial eruption typically appears as a single ovoid macule that is 1–5 cm in diameter, also known as a herald patch. This plaque is usually salmon-colored, slightly raised, and surrounded by a scaly, white collarette. The secondary eruption develops about 2–21 days later and is characterized by bilateral diffuse, oval-shaped papules and plaques that are smaller than the herald patch. Patients can also experience pruritus, for which topical emollients and/ or oral antihistamines may be prescribed. The rash typically resolves spontaneously in 6–12 weeks.

Key learning point: Pityriasis rosea typically begins with a herald patch followed by a diffuse, pruritic eruption of smaller oval lesions and often resolves spontaneously within 6–12 weeks.
Image Description:

Initial eruption (herald patch) and secondary eruption on the trunk

The herald patch (black arrow) is ovoid with a raised dark border and central clearing. The secondary eruption consists of scattered papules and plaques on an erythematous base.
questions.hint: The lesions associated with this condition are oriented along cleavage (Langers) lines, which align on the back like the branches of a Christmas tree, resulting in a characteristic Christmas tree pattern.

questions.text: A 24-year-old woman presents with a 3-week history of rash that began as a single oval lesion on her chest, followed by multiple smaller scaly lesions across her trunk and upper arms. She experienced mild cold-like symptoms one week before the initial lesion appeared. Examination reveals a rash as shown. The lesions are mildly pruritic. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Tinea corporis typically presents with annular lesions that have raised, scaly borders and central clearing, but the characteristic herald patch followed by Christmas tree distribution pattern is not seen with dermatophyte infections.

B) INCORRECT:

Secondary syphilis can present with a papular rash on the trunk, but typically involves the palms and soles, lacks the characteristic herald patch, and does not follow the Christmas tree distribution pattern associated with the correct diagnosis.

C) INCORRECT:

Pityriasis versicolor presents with hypopigmented or hyperpigmented scaly patches, but lacks the herald patch and Christmas tree distribution associated with the correct diagnosis. The lesions are typically smaller and more numerous.

D) INCORRECT:

Drug eruptions can cause widespread papular rashes but typically present with more generalized distribution, lack the characteristic herald patch, and do not follow the Christmas tree pattern associated with the correct diagnosis.

E) CORRECT:

Correct - The clinical presentation is classic for pityriasis rosea with the pathognomonic herald patch (initial single oval lesion with salmon-colored center and dark red border) followed by a secondary eruption distributed in a Christmas tree pattern along skin tension lines.

questions.text: A 27-year-old woman comes to the clinic because of a rash on her trunk and upper arms for five days. She first noticed a single, oval, pink patch with a slightly raised border on her left upper chest about 10 days ago, which has since faded in the center. Over the past week, she has developed several smaller, similar lesions on her abdomen and back. She has mild pruritus but has no pain, fever, or recent upper respiratory symptoms. She has no significant past medical history and takes no medications. She does not smoke, drink alcohol, or use illicit drugs. Vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination shows multiple oval, salmon-colored plaques with a fine, trailing scale distributed along the lines of skin tension in a distinctive bilateral, V-shaped branching arrangement on the back and trunk. There is no mucosal involvement. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Nummular eczema manifests as coin-shaped, well-demarcated plaques, often on the extremities. Lesions are usually intensely pruritic, have a chronic course, and are caused by xerosis. Additionally, the rash distribution is not along skin tension lines, and there is no herald patch, making nummular eczema unlikely in this patient.
Image Description:

Several red-brown, round, crusted, and slightly scaly plaques can be seen on the back of the hands, fingers, and lower arm.

B) CORRECT:

Pityriasis rosea is a type of skin rash that typically begins with an initial eruption in the form of a single ovoid macule or patch (herald patch) that has a slightly raised, dark-red border, a central, salmon-colored clearing zone, and a surrounding collarette. Days to weeks later, a secondary eruption with multiple scaly papules with a similar appearance develops. Lesions often follow the Langer lines of skin tension on the trunk and proximal extremities, creating a characteristic Christmas tree appearance on the back. The rash is typically accompanied by pruritus. Mucosal involvement is rare. Pityriasis rosea is idiopathic but may be caused by a viral infection (e.g., human herpesvirus 6 or 7). The rash typically resolves spontaneously within 6–12 weeks.
Image Description:

A secondary rash after primary plaque formation (not shown) can be seen on the back of this patient. The secondary eruption of pityriasis rosea is usually episodic and distributed along Langer lines.

C) INCORRECT:

Guttate psoriasis is a form of psoriasis that manifests with the sudden onset of multiple, small papules with scale, usually on the trunk and proximal extremities. Lesions in guttate psoriasis are drop-shaped and erythematous with thick scale, which is not consistent with the oval, salmon-colored plaques with a fine, trailing scale. Moreover, lesions in guttate psoriasis are not preceded by an initial eruption, and the rash distribution does not follow a V-shape pattern. Finally, guttate psoriasis occurs mainly after a streptococcal infection, but this patient has no history of infection, making this diagnosis unlikely.
Image Description:

Multiple small scaly erythematous lesions are visible.

This appearance is typical of guttate psoriasis and is most often precipitated by group A streptococcal infection.

D) INCORRECT:

Tinea corporis typically manifests with one or more round, erythematous plaques with raised, scaly borders and central clearing. While the lesions are often pruritic, they are not preceded by an initial eruption and do not follow the skin tension lines or form a V-shape pattern.
Image Description:

A round, well demarcated erythematous lesion with central scaling is visible. The border is raised with several pustules visible.

These features are characteristic of tinea corporis.

E) INCORRECT:

Secondary syphilis can manifest with a generalized rash with macules and papules, but does not typically involve pruritus or a V-shape distribution. Additionally, systemic symptoms (e.g., fever, malaise, lymphadenopathy) and involvement of the palms, soles, and mucous membranes would be expected in secondary syphilis.
Image Description:

Partially confluent and partially scaling red papules and macules of ∼2–5 mm diameter are visible on the palms and wrists.

This appearance is typical of secondary syphilis.
questions.hint: This patient's initial eruption is consistent with a herald patch.
